Admits Mishandling Video of Arab Guerrillas The United Nations said misjudgments and deliberate evasions had occurred in its handling of videotape related to the kidnapping of three Israeli soldiers last October by Lebanese Hezbollah fighters. But investigators said the tape did not have information about the kidnapping itself or shed light on the soldiers' condition. Israel's ambassador expressed satisfaction with the inquiry.

Iraq Defenses Seen as Stronger Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Iraq had rebuilt and even improved its air defenses since American and British planes flew strikes against radar stations and command centers in February.

Help for Argentina and Brazil The International Monetary Fund said it was prepared to lend $15 billion to Brazil and accelerate financial aid for Argentina as concerns rose that financial problems in the two nations had worsened and begun to spread through Latin America.

Russia Frees American John E. Tobin Jr., 24, a Fulbright scholar, was paroled from a Russian prison where he had served about 6 months of a 37-month sentence for a minor marijuana conviction that briefly threatened to blossom into an international espionage drama.

Thai Premier Is Acquitted Thailand's highest court narrowly cleared Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of financial irregularities cited by an anticrime commission. Public opinion had overwhelmingly supported the prime minister.

Wahid Returns to Indonesia Former President Abdurrahman Wahid, who was ousted last month after 21 months in office, returned to Jakarta after a medical checkup in the United States, still sounding angry over his removal and promising to set up a clearinghouse for complaints about the government.

Senate Democrats Yield On Farm Aid Legislation The Senate's Democratic leaders bowed to a White House veto threat and approved a farm aid bill that was $2 billion less than they wanted. President Bush welcomed the voice vote on the $5.5 billion bill as ''a victory for our nation's farmers at a time when they need it the most.''

Bipartisan Alliance on Climate Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, joined forces to warn that the nation's isolation from a global warming pact could hurt business as well as the environment and said they wanted to guide the nation toward mandatory limits on greenhouse gases.

Bush Rates Bush The president, setting off on a monthlong vacation in Texas, said enactment of a tax cut and improved prospects for final legislation defining patients' rights had proved he could end ''deadlock and drift'' in the nation's capital. Some Democrats disputed that assessment, saying Mr. Bush favored bipartisan imagery over bipartisan policy making.

Cheney Rejects Files Request Vice President Dick Cheney, citing constitutional grounds, declined to turn over certain documents sought by Congress in an inquiry into how the Bush administration's energy policy was formed.

Iran Told to Pay Hostage's Kin A federal judge ruled that Iran should pay $314.6 million to the family of the Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, a Roman Catholic priest held hostage in Lebanon by Islamic radicals for nearly 19 months in the 1980's. The suit was filed by the estate of Father Jenco, who died of cancer in Illinois in 1996, and by his siblings.

Bar to Executing the Retarded Gov. Michael F. Easley of North Carolina, a Democrat, plans to sign legislation barring the execution of mentally retarded people, his office said. That would make North Carolina the fifth state to enact such legislation this year. A person is considered mentally retarded under the North Carolina measure if his I.Q. is below 70 and he has significant difficulty in performing basic functions.

Hevesi Hopes to Preserve Parts of Giuliani Legacy Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller and a Democrat, said in an interview that if he were elected mayor he would offer ''the best of Rudy Giuliani without the worst.'' He said he would work to continue driving crime down but would also work to curb police misconduct. Saying public education had been long neglected, he said he would press for smaller classes. And he said he would use city money to create a trust fund to build more affordable housing.

Tougher Museum Rules Urged Mayor Giuliani, displeased with efforts of the panel he appointed to assess standards for art museums, was said to be pressing for stronger language to impair the museums' ability to show work considered profane.

Grappling With Immigration Advocates for the rights of immigrants on Long Island held a rally in Hauppauge to denounce and warn against a weekend conference in Centereach that organizers said would focus on the dangers of illegal immigration and how to fight it.
Shooting at Port Authority Four people were shot when a gunman opened fire on a lower level of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown. One man was arrested on the scene.
Dawn of the Cosmos A multinational team of scientists said the dim haze from a time so ancient that stars and galaxies had not begun to shine had been seen for the first time by earthly telescopes.

U.S. Still Losing Jobs Private-sector payrolls fell by 73,000 jobs in July, similar to the pace of recent months. But unemployment, calculated from separate data, held steady for the second month in a row, at 4.5 percent. Manufacturers -- which often provide a glimpse of where the economy is heading -- cut their fewest number of jobs in 10 months, while layoffs rose in the larger service sector.

The Dow fell 38.40 points, to 10,512.78; the Nasdaq lost 21.05, to 2,066.33; and the S.& P. 500 slid 6.40, to 1,214.35. The Nasdaq was up 1.8 percent for the week, with the Dow and S.& P. 500 up less than 1 percent.

Trans-Atlantic Airline Alliance British Airways and American Airlines said they would try again to gain regulators' approval to provide coordinated information on fares, schedules and reciprocal frequent flyer benefits. A similar plan was blocked five years ago.
Wachovia Goes to First Union Wachovia said it had won shareholder approval for a $13 billion merger with First Union, defeating a hostile takeover attempt by SunTrust Banks.
